When gender identity concerns (typically manifesting as gender dysphoria) first emerge in a child, it is good for a parent to see a psychologist who can then lay out a plan to track this and see whether it persists, as well as to explore the child's concern and where it originates without judgment or weighing on it (either for or against).

If this gender identity persists through initial pubertal stages (but importantly not before, as puberty has been shown to be a major abating factor for early childhood gender dysphoria), then I think the right course would be to start treatment, but rather than social transition or puberty blockers I think the right course would be to skip immediately to HRT.  Puberty blockers are only proposed as a midpoint for people to deliberate their gender identity, but research has shown that almost all people that go on puberty blockers persist to HRT anyway, so there's no point in my opinion to add an additional complicating medication with other potentially deleterious effects.  The important consideration here is that with the help of a psychologist and a waiting strategy that other mediating factors are ruled out and that the gender dysphoria is shown to be persistent such that transition does become the only good course for positive outcomes.  I don't think this type of case needs to be age-gated in the same way the latter might, but I do think it should be gated by physical maturity (no transition treatment of any type for this group prior to onset of puberty).

For the second group, I'm far more skeptical.  Notably the first group is mostly natal males, and the second group is natal females, and I don't believe that's a coincidence.  I think a similar sort of course needs to be pursued for this latter group, but for them I'm fairly strong on limiting any treatment to post-puberty since their dysphoria has manifested later.  Very importantly for this case is to eliminate two potential complicating factors, that being generalized depression and anxiety especially as it might relate to the normal mental distress that people experience around puberty, and also the potential for social contagion effects (which likely wouldn't be a problem for the first group).  If the dysphoria persists to 18+ years old, the child now being an adult would have to agency to choose to do what they want, but I don't trust permitting people younger than 18 *specifically of this group* to be allowed medical intervention if the dysphoria has lasted fewer than 2 years or if there are other antagonizing factors such as the two mentioned above.
